case_title: Messrs GHARIBWAL CEMENT LIMITED and others vs RASHID SADIQ, EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR (ENFORCEMENT AND MONITORING), SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION OF PAKISTAN
court: Appellate Bench of Securities and Exchange Commission of Pakistan
respondant: RASHID SADIQ, EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR (ENFORCEMENT AND MONITORING), SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION OF PAKISTAN

accussed_details.name: Directors of Gharibwal Cement Limited
allegation: Violation of Section 208 of Companies Ordinance, 1984
Failure to obtain prior shareholder approval

complaint_summary: The Executive Director (E&M) alleged that Gharibwal Cement Limited violated Section 208 of the Companies Ordinance, 1984 by making unauthorized investments in Dandot Cement Company Limited exceeding the 30% threshold without prior shareholder approval.
investigation_summary: The Executive Director (E&M) issued a show-cause notice after observing investments and loans made by Gharibwal Cement Limited to Dandot Cement Company Limited. The investigation revealed that these investments were made without prior shareholder approval and were in contravention of Section 208 of the Companies Ordinance, 1984.
judgment_summary: The appellate bench concluded that Gharibwal Cement Limited violated Section 208 of the Companies Ordinance, 1984 by making unauthorized investments in Dandot Cement Company Limited. The penalty imposed on directors was reduced from Rs. 300,000 to Rs. 100,000 per director, and Rs. 200,000 for the CEO. The company was directed to recover any shortfall in returns from Dandot Cement Company Limited within specified timelines.

directions.auditor_certificate: Gharibwal must submit a certificate from its auditors confirming the actual amount to be brought back within 15 days.
directions.shortfall_recovery: Any shortfall indicated in the auditor's certificate must be recovered from Dandot within 30 days, failing which the directors will be held liable.

Decision_or_verdict: Appeal disposed of with reduced penalties and directives for recovery of shortfall.
legal_arguments: Whether ratification by shareholders can rectify violations under Section 208.
Applicability of Section 208 to investments made in associated companies.
Nature of financial facilities provided by Gharibwal to Dandot.
Extent of loss suffered by Gharibwal due to investments in Dandot.
Compliance with Section 195(5) and Section 488 of the Companies Ordinance, 1984.
Buy-back arrangement with Saudi-Pak Leasing and its compliance with Section 208.
assets: 11,429,708 shares of Dandot Cement Company Limited
Purchase of 966,500 shares for Rs 7.3 million
citations: Brooke Bond India Ltd. v. UB Ltd. (1994) 79 Companies Cases 346
Mathura Prasad Saraf v. Company Law Board
East Indian Produce Limited v. Naresh Acharya Bhaduri (1988) 64 Comp. Cas. 259
key_issues: Governance issues in disclosure and shareholder approval
Buy-back arrangement with Saudi-Pak Leasing and its compliance with Section 208

section_208.description: Investments made by Gharibwal in Dandot exceeded the 30% threshold without prior shareholder approval.
section_208.extent: Purchase of 966,500 shares for Rs 7.3 million and advances of Rs 337.8 million.

legal_terms.Associated Company: A company in which another company holds 20% or more of the shareholding.
legal_terms.Special Resolution: A resolution passed by shareholders requiring a higher threshold of approval.

words_and_phrases.Normal Trade Credit: Credit extended in the ordinary course of business transactions.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around violations of Section 208 of the Companies Ordinance, 1984 by Gharibwal Cement Limited due to unauthorized investments in Dandot Cement Company Limited. The appellate bench reduced penalties and directed recovery of shortfall in returns. Key issues include governance compliance, ratification of investments, financial losses, and buy-back arrangements.
